subject: Improving what's output in JUnit HTML report
msgSnippet: I ve been happily using JUnit for years (v3.8.1), and I currently find myself in a situation that requires me to get additional info into the JUnit HTML
messageBody:
I've been happily using JUnit for years (v3.8.1), and I currently find
myself in a situation that requires me to get additional info into the
JUnit HTML report; the default HTML report is no longer sufficient for
our uses. Some issues I have include:

1. We have many test cases and test suites, and it is common to
duplicate a method name in more than one test case. e.g.
testAccessProperties() may appear many times, so if one of them fails,
its not readily obvious WHICH one failed. I usually have included the
name of the test case in the test method's name, but other developers
here aren't willing to do that. e.g.
"testOurTestCase_accessProperties". Test case info should appear in
the results too so that we don't have to creatively name the methods.

2. I'm producing one giant HTML report from the running of several
test suites. Each test suite is usually named AllTests. The
resulting HTML shows a list of test cases all named AllTests, which
isn't all that helpful.

3. It is normal for us to run the same test suite more than once, but
with different data each time. For example, our product has a common
interface to access more than one type of server, so the same set of
tests are invoked against more than one server (and this is controlled
by providing a .properties file to the tests containing different info
about that server). The default behavior of the JUnit ant task
created a file TEST-com.blah.AllTests.xml file which kept getting
overwritten with each subsequent run of the tests against another
server; I solved this with the "outfile" attribute so that each XML
file has a slightly different name, so I can at least preserve the
data. But, the one giant HTML report isn't able to show how one test
run is any different from another since it just lists
"com.blah.AllTests" several times. I need a way to annotate in the
test results what each test run was for, even just a simple text
string would help.

I realize some of these problems could be solved just by creating
several different HTML reports, each in its own directory appropriate
named, and a higher-level HTML file with text descriptions and links
to each HTML report. Although, we'd kind of like one big report.

Has anyone else worked out issues like these? I have done a small
amount of extending JUnit (custom formatters, custom runners), so I'm
not afraid of proceeding down that path. Anyone have tips on what has
worked out well for them?

Thanks!
